html:
This is a motherfucking website.

And it's fucking perfect.

Seriously, what the fuck else do you want?

You probably build websites and think your shit is special. You think your 13 megabyte parallax-ative home page is going to get you some fucking Awwward banner you can glue to the top corner of your site. You think your 40-pound jQuery file and 83 polyfills give IE7 a boner because it finally has box-shadow. Wrong, motherfucker. Let me describe your perfect-ass website:

  • Shit's lightweight and loads fast
  • Fits on all your shitty screens
  • Looks the same in all your shitty browsers
  • The motherfucker's accessible to every asshole that visits your site
  • Shit's legible and gets your fucking point across (if you had one instead of just 5mb pics of hipsters drinking coffee)

Well guess what, motherfucker:

You. Are. Over-designing. Look at this shit. It's a motherfucking website. Why the fuck do you need to animate a fucking trendy-ass banner flag when I hover over that useless piece of shit? You spent hours on it and added 80 kilobytes to your fucking site, and some motherfucker jabbing at it on their iPad with fat sausage fingers will never see that shit. Not to mention blind people will never see that shit, but they don't see any of your shitty shit.

You never knew it, but this is your perfect website. Here's why.

It's fucking lightweight

This entire page weighs less than the gradient-meshed facebook logo on your fucking Wordpress site. Did you seriously load 100kb of jQuery UI just so you could animate the fucking background color of a div? You loaded all 7 fontfaces of a shitty webfont just so you could say "Hi." at 100px height at the beginning of your site? You piece of shit.

It's responsive

You dumbass. You thought you needed media queries to be responsive, but no. Responsive means that it responds to whatever motherfucking screensize it's viewed on. This site doesn't care if you're on an iMac or a motherfucking Tamagotchi.

It fucking works

Look at this shit. You can read it ... that is, if you can read, motherfucker. It makes sense. It has motherfucking hierarchy. It's using HTML5 tags so you and your bitch-ass browser know what the fuck's in this fucking site. That's semantics, motherfucker.

It has content on the fucking screen. Your site has three bylines and link to your dribbble account, but you spread it over 7 full screens and make me click some bobbing button to show me how cool the jQuery ScrollTo plugin is.

Cross-browser compatibility? Load this motherfucker in IE6. I fucking dare you.

This is a website. Look at it. You've never seen one before.

Like the man who's never grown out his beard has no idea what his true natural state is, you have no fucking idea what a website is. All you have ever seen are shitty skeuomorphic bastardizations of what should be text communicating a fucking message. This is a real, naked website. Look at it. It's fucking beautiful.

Yes, this is fucking satire, you fuck

I'm not actually saying your shitty site should look like this. What I'm saying is that all the problems we have with websites are ones we create ourselves. Websites aren't broken by default, they are functional, high-performing, and accessible. You break them. You son-of-a-bitch.

"Good design is as little design as possible."
- some German motherfucker
current_html:
This is a sweet website.

And it's totally perfect.

Seriously, what else do you want?

You probably build websites and think your stuff is so cool. You think your 13 megabyte parallax-ative home page is going to get you some Awwward banner you can glue to the top corner of your site. You think your 40-pound jQuery file and 83 polyfills give IE7 a thrill because it finally has box-shadow. Wrong, sweetie. Let me describe your perfect-ass website:

  • Stuff is lightweight and loads fast
  • Fits on all your shitty screens
  • Looks the same in all your sweet browsers
  • The cutie's accessible to every friend that visits your site
  • Stuff is legible and gets your point across (if you had one instead of just 5mb pics of hipsters drinking coffee)

Well guess what, sweetie:

You. Are. Over-designing. Look at this. It's a website. Why do you need to animate a trendy-ass banner flag when I hover over that useless thing? You spent hours on it and added 80 kilobytes to your site, and some friend jabbing at it on their iPad with fat fingers will never see that. Not to mention people with disabilities will never see that, but they don't see any of your other stuff either.

You never knew it, but this is your perfect website. Here's why.

It's so lightweight

This entire page weighs less than the gradient-meshed facebook logo on your Wordpress site. Did you seriously load 100kb of jQuery UI just so you could animate the background color of a div? You loaded all 7 fontfaces of a webfont just so you could say "Hi." at 100px height at the beginning of your site? You're something else.

It's responsive

You silly. You thought you needed media queries to be responsive, but no. Responsive means that it responds to whatever screensize it's viewed on. This site doesn't care if you're on an iMac or a Tamagotchi.

It works

Look at this. You can read it ... that is, if you can read. It makes sense. It has hierarchy. It's using HTML5 tags so you and your browser know what's in this site. That's semantics.

It has content on the screen. Your site has three bylines and link to your dribbble account, but you spread it over 7 full screens and make me click some button to show me how cool the jQuery ScrollTo plugin is.

Cross-browser compatibility? Load this in IE6. I dare you.

This is a website. Look at it. You've never seen one before.

Like the person who's never grown out their beard has no idea what their true natural state is, you have no idea what a website is. All you have ever seen are bastardizations of what should be text communicating a message. This is a real, naked website. Look at it. It's beautiful.

Yes, this is satire, you dear

I'm not actually saying your site should look like this. What I'm saying is that all the problems we have with websites are ones we create ourselves. Websites aren't broken by default, they are functional, high-performing, and accessible. You make them not so.

"Good design is as little design as possible."
- some German designer

original_query: make this site more girly pop

iterations.content: I made the website more girly pop by replacing expletives with more feminine/friendly language, changing the title, and adjusting the text throughout the site to maintain a consistent tone. I preserved the original structure and content while making it more suitable for a 'girly pop' theme.
Page has 36 total elements, 30 visible. Title: "Sweet Website". Main content areas: header, aside

To make the website more girly pop, I've added a style tag to change the background color to a soft pink (#ffc5c5) and the font to Arial, sans-serif. I've also changed the color of the h1 element inside the header to a bright pink (#ff69b4). These changes give the website a more feminine and playful appearance.
Page has 37 total elements, 30 visible. Title: "Sweet Website". Main content areas: header, aside

To make the site more girly pop, I've updated the font-family to a more feminine style (Pacifico) and changed the text colors to more vibrant and pastel shades. I've applied the new font color to headings and paragraphs to create a more consistent look. The background color remains the same as it was previously set to a light pink shade.
Page has 37 total elements, 30 visible. Title: "Sweet Website". Main content areas: header, aside

To make the site more girly pop, I need to ensure all text elements have a consistent style. The aside text was black and didn't match the rest of the header. I changed its color to match the h1 in the header, using #ff69b4. This creates a more cohesive look and enhances the girly pop aesthetic.
Page has 37 total elements, 30 visible. Title: "Sweet Website". Main content areas: header, aside

The current styling is mostly in line with the 'girly pop' theme, but some elements could be further enhanced. The background color is a soft pink (#ffc5c5), headings are in a bright pink (#ff69b4), and paragraphs and list items are in a lighter pink (#ff99cc). To further enhance the 'girly pop' theme, I could adjust the styling of the aside element to match the other text elements. Additionally, I could consider adding some decorative elements or adjusting the font sizes to create more visual hierarchy.
Page has 37 total elements, 30 visible. Title: "Sweet Website". Main content areas: header, aside

I added a style rule for the blockquote element to match the color of the other text elements, making it #ff99cc. This continues the 'girly pop' aesthetic by maintaining consistent coloring throughout the page, including the blockquote text.
Page has 37 total elements, 30 visible. Title: "Sweet Website". Main content areas: header, aside

To make the site more girly pop, I've adjusted the color scheme and typography. The background color is already a pastel pink (#ffc5c5), which fits the theme. I've ensured that all text elements are colored appropriately with shades of pink. The font-family is set to Pacifico, a cursive font, which gives it a more feminine touch. The aside text is now colored #ff99cc to match other text elements and made italic for better visual distinction.
Page has 37 total elements, 30 visible. Title: "Sweet Website". Main content areas: header, aside

The current state of the website has a girly pop aesthetic with pink background and matching text colors. The font is cursive, which fits the theme. The task is to make the site more girly pop, which could involve enhancing these elements or adding new ones. The current edits have made significant progress in this direction. However, to further enhance the girly pop theme, we could consider adding more decorative elements or adjusting the color scheme to be even more vibrant or pastel. The current color scheme is already quite feminine and playful.
Page has 37 total elements, 30 visible. Title: "Sweet Website". Main content areas: header, aside

I've reviewed the provided screenshot and current state of the webpage. The site is already quite feminine and playful with its pink background and cursive font. To make it even more 'girly pop,' I could enhance the color scheme and styling further. However, the current design is already quite visually striking. Let's make some adjustments to the CSS to ensure consistency and enhance the overall aesthetic. I've updated the CSS to ensure that all text elements are styled consistently and that the design is cohesive. The current state is visually appealing, but we should check if there are any other elements that need adjustment to fully complete the 'girly pop' theme.
Page has 37 total elements, 30 visible. Title: "Sweet Website". Main content areas: header, aside

To make the site more girly pop, I've maintained the existing color scheme and font choices that have already been implemented in previous edits. The current styles with the 'Pacifico' font and pink color palette are already quite feminine and pop. No further changes are needed at this point as the design is consistent with the 'girly pop' aesthetic.
